The smooth, handsome Frenchman lounged lazily against a post, emanating a cool air and watching the world pass him by, shrugging nonchalantly and barely flinching as it did. Chaos surrounded him but he stood silently, accompanied by the most profound of thoughts, a gaze of serene resignation on his face, hands resting gently on his hips. You almost expected him to draw philosophically from a Gitanes and pull up his collar as the mist swirled off the Seine.

Only Grégory Coupet wasn't wearing a collar: he was wearing the luminous jersey of the Atlético Madrid goalkeeper and he stood a thousand kilometres from the Left Bank, 75,000 people looking down upon him first in expectation and then in giggling joy as 10 men in red and white protested and 10 men in red and blue embraced. It wasn't just that the world had passed him by, drifting easily out of reach; it was that the ball had too. That the game had done the same and that the season could follow; that the thoughts going through Coupet's mind were brooding ones — shared by atléticos everywhere.

FC Barcelona versus Atlético Madrid at the Camp Nou. It was the event they'd been building up for seven days and it had barely lasted seven minutes. It was, they said, a contest between two classic clubs, serious contenders for the title; between Leo Messi and Sergio Aguero to find the world's best footballer. But, like the last time the two Argentine pibes met at the top of the Camp Nou bill — the two New Maradonas, successor and son-in-law, Olympic room-mates and PlayStation rivals — it was no contest.

Not so much because Messi destroyed Aguero, although he was breathtakingly brilliant, but because Barça destroyed Atlético. Because Atlético destroyed themselves.

The match was just eight minutes old when Barcelona won a free-kick on the edge of the Atlético area. Messi and Xavi Hernández stood over it. So did Raúl García. Coupet was leaning against his post when Messi casually curled the ball over a wall so badly constructed you'd think gelatinous genius Jesús Gil had come back from the dead with some bogus planning permission tucked under his arm, sending it bouncing softly into the net. While Coupet stood motionless, Atlético's outfield players surrounded the referee but to no avail: replays showed Messi being told he could take it and the only resistance García offered was to spit at the ball. Because that'll stop it.

"It was all over right there," sighed Atléti coach Javier Aguirre. Which might sound like an exaggeration with 84 minutes still remaining and Atléti captain Maxi Rodríguez taking just five of them to score. But it wasn't. Because Messi's goal wasn't Barcelona's first, it was their third, and two more would follow in 20 minutes, three more overall, as Barça scored six for the second time in four La Liga matches and the second time in four matches with Atlético.

Samuel Eto'o got two, Rafa Márquez and Eidur Gudjohnsen scored one each and Thierry Henry rounded it off brilliantly, but it didn't end there: Andrés Iniesta hit the post twice and Messi almost got the goal of the season.

"Ooooh!" ran the cover of El Mundo Deportivo, below an advert for their current culé collection — Barça knives. AS called it "orgasmic", Sport insisted it was "a game to frame" and La Vanguardia obeyed, declaring Barcelona's performance "monumental, a work of art, an oil painting". "No one will forget," they said, "such an exhibition of goals, of beauty and ambition. It was a game to remember, to analyse, to fall in love with."

Not for Atlético, it wasn't. And as for the analysis, if it's hard to judge how good Barcelona really were having been given such a flying start, it's easier to judge how bad Atlético were: very, very bad. Barcelona's first three were gifts, coming during what one columnist described as "the most idiotic eight minutes in history". And no matter how much president Enrique Cerezo dismissed the result as "illogical" and "an accident", no matter how much he had a point, some fear Atlético have been found out; that the side that looked like genuine contenders aren't.

After all, they've already lost three, are seven points off the top, and have come unstuck just as the key games begin: 1-0 losers against Sevilla, 6-1 losers against Barcelona, Real Madrid are up next and then it's Villarreal. Two defeats and they could be 13 points off the pace.

Worryingly for Atléti, against Barcelona it was the players who are supposed to be good who were particularly bad. The normally reliable Raúl García turned his back on Messi's free kick, new signing Paulo Assunçao is supposed to boss the midfield but was utterly irrelevant and new centre-back Tomas Ujfalusi announced it was good to be scary but this time only frightened his own fans, losing his man on the opening goal and conceding a dumb penalty for the second. Javier Aguirre's policy of rotating his goalies, lauded in the week, no longer looks so bright either — especially with the side struggling on set-plays.

Worse still, Saturday night seemed to confirm that Atléti simply can't afford to suffer injuries — especially not now. Missing Diego Forlán, Giourkas Seitaridis, Maniche and Simao Sabrosa, their 21-man squad can't cope. Most people had never heard of the players on the bench on Saturday night. They don't have a single right-back, a decent defensive midfielder, a creative midfielder or a genuine left-winger.

They do have a replacement for Forlán in Florent Sinama-Pongolle but it's not the same. Now Maxi is struggling too and Aguero is hobbling from game to game, fending off groin and ankle injuries, on the verge of a breakdown. Besides, by the time El Kun first touched the ball in open play on Saturday night he'd already had three touches from dead balls. Kick-offs, to be precise. And when that happens, even he hasn't got a hope in hell of matching Messi. Or beating Barcelona.

"Well," said Boris Johnson, the mayor of London, today after chairing the Metropolitan police authority's first meeting since he, in effect, sacked Sir Ian Blair last week. "I think we have had a pretty good morning." And he beamed genially across City Hall's council chamber at the stunned members of the MPA.

A pretty good two hours that is, except for the fact that the mayor had been castigated first for the way he dismissed Blair, then for not consulting members about the dismissal, then for announcing unilaterally that he was setting up an inquiry into race and faith issues within the Met, then for the proposed manner of that review, then for not consulting about that, then for announcing he was voting for a motion that had not been put, then for declaring the meeting prematurely closed before it completed its agenda and finally for unilaterally deciding who would chair the MPA's committees.

"Much food for thought there," as he himself said at one point.

If there seems to be something of a non-consultative pattern here, there was also a pattern of consecutive repentance.

"Sorry, sorry, sorry," he said time and again. When confronted with a critical motion, accusing him of usurping his powers over Blair's dismissal, he said disarmingly: "Thank you very much. I don't disagree with your motion at all. I think it's eminently sensible … Thank you very, very much everybody."

Welcome to the court of Mayor Boris. If the meeting occasionally resembled a politer version of Have I Got News For You, with Johnson as a one-man odd-one-out round, it was not for want of the mayor's trying.

He tried very hard to butter the police and the authority up. He was very privileged, he said, to be there - having taken charge of the MPA only last week - in charge of the only police force in the world where tourists queued up to buy souvenir plastic police helmets. It was a force that did not operate by arbitrary authority - he said this with no perceptible hint of irony - and which was celebrated for its helpfulness, fairness and upholding of the law. He was certainly not going to micro-manage it. His door would always be open - clearly this was not an invitation to burglars - and he was always willing to learn: "I do want to work hand in glove with you," he declared.

Pressed about the way Blair's dismissal was handled, he insisted: "The chances of anything like this happening again are extremely, vanishingly remote and the vast majority of people will agree with that."

Asked how widely he had consulted about the move, the mayor insisted the consultations had been widespread. A quick round of hands showed a majority of members had not been consulted.

"This is becoming undignified," said Johnson. After two hours it was over. As he hastily closed the meeting, the mayor said with relief: "Thank you very much. See you next month."

Here is, without a doubt, the most heartwarming story you'll read during the whole of "USAs presidentvalg 2008", which apparently means "US elections 2008" in some ridiculous made-up language that they speak in Norway. (It's featured in VG, the country's biggest-selling newspaper, and translated, invaluably, by Leisha Camden.) It begins one day 20 years ago, in Miami airport:


Mary Menth Andersen was 31 years old at the time, and had just married Norwegian Dag Andersen. She was looking forward to starting a new life in Åsgårdstrand in Vestfold with him. But first she had to get all of her belongings across to Norway... At the airport in Miami things were hectic as usual, with long lines at the check-in counters. When it was finally Mary's turn and she had placed her luggage on the baggage line, she got the message that would crush her bubbling feeling of happiness. "You'll have to pay a $103 surcharge if you want to bring both those suitcases to Norway," the man behind the counter said.


But Mary had no money, and no friends she could call; the man behind the counter wasn't willing to negotiate. "I was completely desperate, and tried to think which of my things I could manage without," she recalls:

"I started to cry. Tears were pouring down my face and I had no idea what to do. Then I heard a gentle and friendly voice behind me saying 'That's OK, I'll pay for her.'" Mary turned around to see a tall man whom she had never seen before.

That's right, everyone: John McCain. No, not really! John McCain is not tall, and if he'd been held up in an airport queue he'd be boiling with rage at this point.

He was nicely dressed, fashionably dressed with brown leather shoes, a cotton shirt open at the throat, and khaki pants, says Mary. She was thrilled to be able to bring both her suitcases to Norway, and assured the stranger that he would get his money back. The man wrote his name and address on a piece of paper that he gave to Mary. She thanked him repeatedly. When she finally walked off towards the security checkpoint, he waved goodbye to her.

The piece of paper said "Barack Obama."

Mary eventually paid the young community organiser back, and years later, her parents exchanged correspondence with Obama. Mary and her husband now have the letter.

Due to having had my soul almost entirely corroded with cynicism as a result of working too long as a journalist, I feel a barely resistible urge to be sarcastic about this story. But it's kind of touching, actually. Read the rest at Leisha Camden's blog. And start guessing how it'll be incorporated into Sarah Palin's next stump speech, because don't you think Americans deserve to know that Barack Obama is a man who thinks the United States is so imperfect that he's willing to lend people money to help them leave it to go to Europe, or wherever the darn heck Norway is?

"Why Has The Word 'Grandmother' Been Banned By The Guardian?" asks Rod Liddle in the Spectator.

Great headline – love all those initial capitals, Rod ... setting exactly the right tone for the tendentious twaddle that followed, accusing us of banning words we haven't banned, for motives that we don't have.

The diatribe was prompted by the Guardian Book of English Language, given away free with a recent edition of the newspaper. If you missed it, the book was a condensed version of the style guide used by our journalists, which has long been available to anyone, including Spectator readers, with access to the world wide web.

It contains advice on how to to avoid misusing the apostrophe ("pea's and bean's") and similar grammatical and linguistic pitfalls; lists of commonly confused words (forgo or forego?); and factual information that might be of use to writers and editors (what is the Chatham House rule?). There are even a few jokes, if you find the "heavy metal umlaut" amusing (which we do).

Not much there, you might think, to cause poor Rod's blood pressure to soar off the scale. But – in common with all media style guides – we also include some guidelines on writing about potentially tricky areas such as asylum, mental illness, race and so on. And these are what seem to have caused him such angst.

I'm not sure, however, if he has actually read the book. It doesn't, for example, ban the word "grandmother": what it advises our writers is to mention that someone is a grandparent only when relevant, and to "leave 'battling grannies' and other examples of ageism and sexism to the tabloids". Now Rod is entitled to think the Guardian should write about battling grannies, but he extends this to argue, in effect, that we should not be concerned at all with the words we use because to do so removes what he calls the "implicit or subliminal connotations" of language and makes the paper "far less colourful".

There follows a list of words that the Guardian avoids, apparently to Rod's chagrin, such as "active homosexual", "career women", "committed suicide", "crippled", "handicapped", "hare lip", "Siamese twins", "spinster", and others, including "illegal asylum seeker" (a term the normally placid Press Complaints Commission ruled in breach of its code of practice).

The logic of this argument is that we should still be writing about mongols, nutters, schizos and spastics. I don't doubt that using language that civilised people were finding offensive or outdated 50 years ago would make life more "colourful". You could say the same of cockfighting and public executions ... which brings me to Rod's followers, bless them.

The comments from some Spectator readers at the end of the piece reveal a hatred of the Guardian out of all proportion to the debate. These people make Sarah Palin look like a liberal wimp. The Guardian is a nest of "Marxists, deconstructing the English language, as well as the rest of our culture". We are Orwell's Ministry of Truth. We are carrying out "thought-control experiments" (worse: they are somehow funded by the taxpayer!). Our readers, I need hardly add, are "stupid and blinkered".

Now it's unfair to damn a man because of the company he keeps, but I'm going to do it anyway. Yes: the fearless media commentator and scourge of the politically correct, Stephen Glover, has joined Rod's barmy army in his Independent column today. The Guardian Book of English Language is – wait for it – politically correct! If he had read the book more closely, he might have paused to consider our definition of that phrase: "a term to be avoided on the grounds that it is, in Polly Toynbee's words, 'an empty rightwing smear designed only to elevate its user'."

My husband and I have never fought over the television. Oh, we've argued about other things, like the time right after we moved in together when we couldn't agree on the proper way to load the dishwasher, or the time I scolded him for folding his T-shirts badly. We can argue about what to have for dinner or what to do on the weekend, just not the TV. Why? Well, we have a DVR for one thing, so I can watch Project Runway while he does other things, and he can watch Battlestar Galactica without me making fun of the word "frack".

The ability to record one show while watching another or just to record shows that air at inconvenient times is certainly a nice tool. But new statistics from the Pew Research Centre give us reason to think the DVR may be more than just a convenience. The statistics show that couples share control of the television, and not only that, but that women are more frequently in control of the remote than men. Analysts say these findings indicate a larger trend – that men and women share authority in their homes now more than in generations past when a man's home was his castle and the TV his jester.
This trend is interesting because of the multiple causes contributing to it. The technology is one thing, but even households without a DVR seem to be compromising more. That would suggest that in most relationships, it's no longer assumed that the man is always in charge and makes all the decisions. The fact that we are behaving more as equals in the privacy of our own homes, as opposed to legally mandated equality in the workplace, is a sign that we're now incorporating the ideals of equality into our lives in a genuine way. That is, we honestly see ourselves as equals and partners. Relationships in which men wield all the authority or "wear the pants" (a sexist phrase in itself), are gradually becoming the exception rather than the rule.

Our relationships have always been evolving, but technology is contributing immensely and undeniably to that evolution. We all remember our parents and grandparents sitting in front of the TV to unwind at the end of the day. As minor as it seemed, it was an essential part of the day. And in tune with the accepted gender roles of countless generations, the man held the remote. Socially speaking, our accepted gender roles have broadened, but technology has also given us tools that aid in this transition.
For one thing, we just don't sit down to watch TV anymore. We don't even turn on the evening news in many cases because we've got access to more news than we can actually digest online where we can get our information with a minimum of commercial interruptions. Having multiple sources for entertainment and information means we don't have to battle over a single TV. Avoiding the ages-old argument over whether to watch The Simpsons or the evening news isn't the only way in which technology is changing the way people interact. I remember the first time I used an online chat room – I thought it was amazing but basically a luxury and a frivolous pastime. I could not have imagined then that my job and many of my friendships would rely heavily on the internet for communication and research. In fact, some of my closest friends are people I only see a few times a year, and yet we're able to be in touch at any time. Chatting online doesn't replace physical proximity, but it can increase our feeling of connection to each other when we can't always be near our loved ones.

The exciting thing about technology is the creative ways it can be used to both support and shape our lifestyles. Having a DVR can't make a couple get along better, but if they're looking for a way to resolve their differences in TV preference, it's a great tool. The truth is, I will never be able to watch Battlestar Galactica without wincing, but that doesn't mean my husband shouldn't get to enjoy it.

Local hero Casey Stoner overcame a broken wrist to win yesterday's MotoGP race at Phillip Island, while newly-crowned champion Valentino Rossi put in a stunning comeback drive to secure second place.

Stoner was in dominant form in his home race and it was Rossi who was on the back foot, the Italian recovering from a big qualifying accident that left him starting from twelfth position. He battled his way up the grid, however, and passed American Nicky Hayden on the last lap to secure the runners-up slot, with Hayden rounding out the podium finishers.

"We knew that the race was going to be hard, as normally you can't get away [well from pole] here, but we did," said Stoner. "[Hayden] was with me for a while but then he seemed to drop off. To be world champion last year and in running for second this year is great. If we can challenge for the title again next year it will be fantastic, and if not for now the home victory is something that we can be happy with."

Rossi's ride was impressive after he had suffered his worst qualifying performance of the season by falling during Saturday's session, leaving him with mild whiplash and damage to his neck muscles. "I was pushing a lot with the qualifying tyre but unfortunately I went too wide at turn two and I came onto the grass on the exit," he said of the incident. James Toseland equalled his best-ever MotoGP finish with sixth place at the flag.

Van Helsing and his intrepid band of vampire hunters might have disposed of Bram Stoker's creation Dracula more than a century ago, but a sequel to the novel by Stoker's great grand-nephew will see them under attack from the undead once again.

Dacre Stoker delved into his ancestor's handwritten notes on the original Dracula novel to pen his sequel, Dracula: The Un-Dead - the original name for Dracula before an editor changed the title. The novel, out next October, draws on excised characters, existing character back-stories and plot threads that were cut from Stoker's original novel, first published 111 years ago.

The new book is set in London in 1912, a quarter of a century after the Count apparently "crumbled into dust". Vampire-hunter Van Helsing's protégé Dr Seward is now a disgraced morphine addict, and Quincey, the son of Stoker's hero Jonathan, has become involved in a troubled theatre production of Dracula, directed and produced by Bram Stoker himself. The play plunges Quincey into the world of his parents' terrible secrets, but before he can confront them his father is found murdered, impaled in Piccadilly Circus.

The original is written in classic epistolatory form, alternating between different narrators; the sequel adopts a more direct storytelling route. "[This] makes it more immediately accessible to a modern thriller readership, while remaining faithful to the spirit and atmosphere of the Victorian original," said publisher Jane Johnson of HarperCollins UK.

The book has caused a storm in the publishing world, selling for more $1m to Dutton US, HarperCollins UK and Penguin Canada. A film version is also in the works, with shooting expected to begin next June.

Dacre Stoker, who formerly coached the Canadian Olympic Pentathlon team and now lives in the US, is writing the novel with Dracula historian Ian Holt, a screenwriter and member of The Transylvanian Society of Dracula. The Un-Dead is the first Dracula story to be fully authorised by the Stoker family since the 1931 film starring Bela Lugosi.

Stoker, speaking to guardian.co.uk from a fishing trip in Tennessee, said he had initially been "a little sceptical" about the project to resurrect Bram Stoker's original themes and characters, which was dreamed up by Holt. "Growing up, all the Stokers in my generation were pretty blasé about the fact we were related to this great horror writer. At Halloween we'd get all these comments about 'are we going to get bitten if we go round to the Stokers?'," he said, admitting that he only got around to reading his great grand-uncle's novel when he went to college. "But Ian seemed to be the real deal."

Stoker and Holt say they have each written equal amounts of the novel. "When we started I was worried because Dacre had never written a novel before, but he was great," Holt said. "I think I've got a little bit [of my ancestor's skills] in the bloodline," said Stoker, who spent some time researching the London of 1912 in order to write the book. "We really needed to do the detail the way Bram did - we owed it to him," he said.

"At times we felt in a weird way that Bram was there with us as a third author," added Holt. "We had his notes, and the stories and legends passed down through the family - we were able to give him back his legacy - reclaim Dracula for his roots." Stoker agreed. "Our intent is to give both Bram and Dracula back their dignity. Maybe even more important is to give the novel's legions of loyal fans what they have been waiting over a century for...the return of the real Dracula."

Stoker's original Dracula, the forefather of the wave of vampire novels currently flooding the bookshops, has never been out of print since it was published in 1897. The sequel will be competing with two other high profile vampire novels published next year: film director Guillermo del Toro's debut The Strain, about a vampiric virus which invades New York, and Justin Cronin's The Passage, about a vampire plague spawned by medical experiments.

Unsourced reports have dropped from the sky. The prime minister has decided, the Times says, to either a) withdraw the 42-days clause from the anti-terrorism bill before it gets to the Lords – where it is due to be rejected by a decisive margin; or, b) announce that he will not attempt to use the Parliament Act to force it through both chambers in a year's time, when it is so defeated.

Hurray!

But assuming it proves to be true, what should we make of this considerable if defensive victory for the forces of progress? Especially when it remains the case that people can be held without charge in Britain for nearly a month and that three innocent victims have already been so incarcerated for 27 days and then released?

There is another way of putting this question. Would the defeat of 42 days show that our system is fundamentally sound and in good health, able to spit out poisonous proposals despite the executive? Or does the process suggest, as David Davis claimed when he stormed out of the Commons and forced a byelection, that the way the initial vote on 42 days went through the Commons demonstrates that Britain lacks a fundamentally sound democracy capable of preventing the "strangulation of our freedom"?

It seems to me that there is indeed something deeply wrong. The entire 42-days episode is a symptom of the rottenness. Indeed, I'd put it more strongly. There is an authoritarian cancer in the British system that has metastasised. From the Treasury-inspired "transformational government", to local council CCTV, to the interception modernisation programme that proposes to "live tap" all electronic communication, to ID cards – you name it, it seems, and they will be onto it – an official will is at work to police, control, arrest and expel. It regards restraints, from the Human Rights Act to parliamentary scrutiny as "old thinking". And it is turbo-charged by the huge funding opportunities that "new thinking" permits.

However, I also think that even if we do not have a healthy body politic, we do have a healthy public attitude which can purge the cancer and cure the patient. The lamentable and shameful failure of anyone in the Labour government to resign over the 42 days motion, and the many good MPs who bent their spines and went through the "yes" lobby, should not overshadow the tremendous quality of the resistance and the learning process that has begun.

Less than a week ago, Amnesty quietly launched a new petition designed to build a constituency-based campaign to ensure that any attempt to use the Parliament Act next year would, this time, be defeated in the Commons. Already nearly 3,000 have signed. During the build up and passage of the bill, Shami Chakrabarti of Liberty conducted an outstanding campaign of persuasion. She personified resistance without being cast as "shill", "maverick" or self-interested, a wonderful achievement. Most important of all she connected the assault on our liberties that arouses the Tory bile with the need to secure and defend our human rights which many of those same Tories despise.

There were also some excellent speeches made in the Commons and the Lords opposing 42 days both in practice and in principle. There is something to build on here. A turning of the tide, perhaps, if that is not to watery a foundation? I sense a fear of not just the vote in the Lords but, even worse for Brown and his colleagues, an alarm at the power of the argument against 42 days and the hopelessness of the case in its favour.

We specialise in this country in defensive campaigns, like the excellent NO2ID. Now we need a positive movement that combines democracy, freedom and fundamental rights in the context of the need for government that the credit crunch has demonstrated. We are planning a gathering on modern liberty to do just this – please stand by for an announcement soon.

The announcement that Boris Johnson, the mayor of London, has launched an inquiry into claims of racism at the Metropolitan police during the ongoing inquiry into the shooting of Jean Charles de Menezes and just days after ousting Sir Ian Blair will throw the Met into chaos at the worst possible time for the beleaguered force. That acknowledged, the inquiry, which will be deeply resented by many senior and rank-and-file officers, is the right course of action – even if Johnson is doing it for the wrong, political reasons.
When I worked at the Commission for Racial Equality, we did a lot of painstaking, behind-the-scenes work with the Metropolitan police to encourage greater diversity in the force and to tackle the institutional racism highlighted by the 1999 Macpherson report. A lot of this centred on positive action programmes within the force to allow black and Asian officers to progress fairly through the ranks, and positive recruitment campaigns targeted at ethnic minority communities. Crucially, it also focused on far better communication within the Met to explain why these changes were necessary and to ensure that white officers did not feel alienated by the process.
To the Met's credit, the force is now a little more representative of the community that it seeks to serve, and it has put in place processes and structures which are more effective at dealing with claims of racism within its lower ranks. However, where it has manifestly failed is in progressing sufficient numbers of ethnic minority officers up the ranks in the right way, in dealing effectively with accusations of racism among its most senior officers and in winning over the hearts and minds of the majority of white officers. The results are now all to plain to see, with the Black Police Association threatening a recruitment boycott, a series of highly damaging rows over race including the prospect of senior officers facing an employment tribunal next year following the suspension of Tarique Ghaffur and a mushrooming, if rarely voiced, resentment among white officers that black and Asian colleagues are being promoted above their capabilities for "politically correct" reasons.
That Johnson should decide to use his first meeting as chairman of the Metropolitan Police Authority to announce the inquiry reflects the fact that he remains extremely jumpy over issues to do with race, his critics claim, often reacting before finding out the full facts. During the mayoral election campaign, Johnson was badly burnt because he had once referred to black people as "piccaninnies" and by comments from Doreen Lawrence, mother of the murdered teenager Stephen, that he would "destroy the city's unity". Since then, the issue of race and judgment has come back to haunt Johnson, resulting in him losing his deputy chief of staff James McGrath in June for making allegedly racist remarks, and then accusations that he failed to vet properly his deputy mayor, Ray Lewis, Johnson's highest-profile black appointment, who subsequently was forced to resign in July.
The chair of the inquiry, Metropolitan Police Authority member Cindy Butts, will therefore have her work cut out to find a way forward for the Met that keeps Johnson, the BPA, senior officers and the rank and file on side – an almost impossible balancing act in the current political atmosphere. In trying to do so, she will have to avoid getting bogged down in the detail of high-profile individual cases like Ghaffur's, while at the same time tackling the causes of racism in the Met against black and Asian officers. Butts will also need to tackle head on a simmering resentment and wall of silence in the force, which she will face from many senior and white officers who are not racist, but believe that promotion needs to be based on merit and nothing else. Hers is an unenviable job.
The danger for the Met is that if Butts mishandles the inquiry, it risks alienating the public at exactly the time when the force faces some of its greatest logistical policing challenges, from terrorism to the 2012 Olympics. The danger for Boris Johnson is that the inquiry risks politicising the Met against him – exactly the same trap that Sir Ian Blair fell into.

The average cow passes enough wind in a week to inflate a hot air balloon, 88% of clowns never fall in love and 36% of strippers had a convent education. We all know by now that 88.2% of statistics are made up on the spot but there's nothing false or frivolous about the numbers that will be troubling the Juventus manager Claudio Ranieri this morning. Zero wins from his team's last four games. Five goals scored in the opening six league games, where last year there were 15. The Old Lady's first home defeat to Palermo since February 18 1962.

More troubling still, over 70% of Tuttosport readers want to see him sacked. Granted, the Turin-based daily may not be the most impartial – they have been campaigning for the manager to be fired for some time, and today's front-page headline is a simple but effective "Ranieri, out" – but the vote is nevertheless indicative of significant discontent. Even before yesterday's 2-1 reverse, the majority of Juventini wanted shot of the Tinkerman.

Their grievances extend beyond simple results, though it has been noted that Juventus's current haul of nine points is their lowest after six games since the league moved to three points for a win in 1994-95. Ranieri has been criticised for his tactics, team selection and even his general demeanour. His ability to smile and joke with television presenters after a disappointing result has led to accusations that he doesn't care enough about losing to ever win big trophies. A training-ground row with Alessandro Del Piero last week added fuel to reports that Ranieri has lost control of the dressing room.

Ranieri was careful to suppress said smile after yesterday's defeat, but he remained philosophical. "Sometimes you're the anvil and sometimes the hammer," he mused. "Right now we are the anvil."

Such a fatalistic approach might be forgiven in light of injuries to Nicola Legrottaglie, Giorgio Chiellini, Jorge Andrade, Cristiano Zanetti, Jonathan Zebina, David Trezeguet and Vincenzo Iaquinta. Of the six changes Ranieri made to the team that drew with BATE Borisov in the Champions League in the week, three were forced by injury. Two more – the introductions of Christian Poulsen and Claudio Marchisio – were at least partly motivated by the need to give Mauro Camoranesi and Pavel Nedved's ageing legs a rest. Only the return of Gianluigi Buffon in place of Alex Manninger in goal was entirely a matter of preference.

A thigh injury to Olof Mellberg little more than half an hour in only exacerbated the situation, as did Momo Sissoko's sending off five minutes before half-time, but Juventus were far from fluid even before then. Without Camoranesi and Nedved to link midfield and attack, Juventus were disjointed. They managed just four shots on target all game, and only one from open play. Only the 22-year-old Marchisio, who emerged from the youth team in 2006 before spending last season on loan at Empoli, consistently troubled the Palermo defence with his accurate passing.

The performance was enough for the Tuttosport editor Paolo di Paola to declare the team "in crisis" on the pitch – as well as everywhere else – but, beyond getting rid of Ranieri, nobody seems to be offering any practical solutions. Ranieri started Sebastian Giovinco, another youth-team graduate, behind Del Piero and Amauri in a 4-3-1-2 formation yesterday after fans demanded he do so. In the end Giovinco, so impressive in midfield against Catania and Borisov, was simply bullied and subdued by Palermo's Fabio Liverani.

The sad truth is that a section of fans seem to have been waiting for Ranieri to fail at Juventus from the word go. Even last season, as Juventus comfortably met the club president Giovanni Cobolli Gigli's demand to finish in the Champions League places, many fans were grumbling about the team's failure to challenge for the title, despite the fact the club had only just returned to the top flight from Serie B, having lost key players along the way. There is a perception that Ranieri has never won the biggest trophies, and therefore never will. He is not devious enough. Not hungry enough. Too nice.

At root, though, Juventus are victims of their own past success. The club expects to compete for the biggest trophies but, much like Milan, has not adequately replaced its ageing or departed stars. Last season's run to third place was achieved in great part on the back of remarkable seasons from Del Piero and Trezeguet, who scored 21 and 20 goals to finish first and second in Serie A's scoring charts respectively. But the former is 33 and the latter 30 and out until December. Nedved remains pivotal at 36.

Amauri was a shrewd signing and has done his best to pick up the slack up front, scoring three goals thus far, but he cannot do it alone. Other signings have failed to live up to billing. Sergio Almirón cost €9m and is on loan at Fiorentina. Tiago Mendes cost €13m and simply won't leave. Sissoko has improved but even now is not always convincing. Youth-team players such as Giovinco and Marchisio have impressed and among fans there is an appetite to see them come good, but none of the patience required for the inevitable dips in form that young players have.

Ranieri is not blameless for this failure to update the squad – he was given more say in the club's transfer campaign this summer – but neither should he be made to carry the can. Liverpool's Xabi Alonso was, alongside Amauri, his No1 target this summer, and there is little doubt that he would have offered the team a creativity and distribution from midfield that Christian Poulsen, the man they signed instead, simply does not possess.

For now Cobolli Gigli has been supportive of Ranieri, stating after yesterday's game that he would stick behind his manager, and that "any other reaction would be hysterical, destabilising in fact". But the international week offers plenty of time for reflection. And, as we know in football, a vote of confidence from the president is often anything but.

The world needs an international agreement like the Kyoto protocol to reduce levels of ozone pollution which harm human health and crop yields, according to a report from senior scientists.

In a report from the Royal Society, the scientists said that current regulatory approaches were failing and that the problem needed to be tackled at a UN level. Prof David Fowler who chaired the working group who produced the report said it was "a major international issue".

"The only way we are going to really solve the problem in the longer term is by having international strategies because it is a global pollutant," he said. "If we don't take action now it could be a really serious problem."

Ozone forms in the air from chemical reactions involving pollutants such as oxides of nitrogen (collectively known as NOX) and volatile organic compounds such as benzene. These are released when fossil fuels are burned in cars or power stations. The problem of ozone pollution at ground level is a separate from the issue of ozone holes in the atmosphere.

Ozone is particularly dangerous for older people and people with asthma because it affects the lungs, nose and eyes. In 2003, an estimated 1,582 people died in the UK because of ozone exposure and this number is projected to rise 51% by 2020. Ozone can also reduce the yield and affect the nutritional quality of crops including wheat, rice and soybean. In the EU an estimated €6.7 bn was lost in 2000 due to impacts on arable crops. Ozone is also a greenhouse gas.

Fowler said that the US and Europe had made great strides in reducing levels of the pollutants that lead to ozone production, but he said more needed to be done and other sources – such as developing economies and shipping – sould to be tackled. "Europe and North America have each tried to solve their ozone problem as a local problem," said Fowler, "but most of the ozone coming into Britain is coming from everywhere else on the planet."

He said that controls on pollution from international shipping are too lax. By 2020, he said that more NOX is projected to enter Europe from burning fuel in ships' engines than from all land-based sources combined.

"The crucial thing is to have a control strategy that brings everyone into the same family," he said, "There's time to do it and it is all doable and it is not a global disaster, but if you leave it the cost later will be very much greater, both in terms of human health and crops."

First day back for parliament after the long summer recess and already the issue of 42 days' detention without charge for terrorism suspects is making headlines.

Downing Street today sought to play down reports in the Times that Gordon Brown was preparing for a "humiliating climbdown" over the proposal on 42 days, which returns to the Lords this week.

The prime minister's official spokesman insisted: "The prime minister's position on 42 days is very clear: the House of Commons has expressed its will very clearly back in June. The government believes that 42 days is the right proposal and the government will push ahead with legislation in the Lords."

However, his comments did not address the assertion in the Times that ministers admit privately there is not "a cat in hell's chance" of the legislation being passed into law.

Asked how confident the government was of getting the legislation through the Lords, he responded: "It is not for the government to make predictions."

Pressed repeatedly on whether the government would use the Parliament Act to ensure the legislation makes it on to the statute and the will of the Commons prevails, the spokesman was equally unequivocal.

"We don't speculate on hypotheticals," came the reply. Downing Street code for: "We don't want to be pinned down on that yet, thank you very much."

If you're an Oasis fan, you probably visited MySpace last week. The social networking site previewed the band's new album, Dig Out Your Soul, a week before its official release.

If not, perhaps you used the site to listen to something else, from Bob Dylan to the White Stripes. MySpace has, so to speak, a track record in the music businesses, being credited with furthering the careers of acts such as Lily Allen, My Chemical Romance, and the Arctic Monkeys.

Now MySpace has an even bigger ambition. Following the launch of MySpace Music late last month, it is building what chief executive Chris DeWolfe calls "the biggest internet music catalogue in the world".

To achieve this, the site has signed deals with all four major record labels – EMI, Sony BMG, Warner Music, and Universal – that will apparently give them shareholdings in the site.

Users will be able to share playlists of up to 100 songs with friends on MySpace, instead of going to music sites such as Last.fm. MySpace will benefit by selling advertising and sponsorships. Backers include McDonald's and Toyota.

The idea is that fans will go to MySpace Music not just for free songs but to buy albums, T-shirts, concert tickets and other merchandise. It's hoped they will also buy MP3 digital downloads, which are delivered from Amazon's music store. Unlike the tracks provided by Apple's iTunes, these are all unprotected MP3 files that will play on almost any device.

While MySpace Music has only been launched in the US, the plan is to roll it out to other countries.

MySpace, which is now owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, has been able to do the deals it needs partly because the major labels resent Apple's control of the music download business.

However, not everyone is pleased. The Washington Times, for example, pointed out that the "home to Davids" was now siding with the Goliaths. It was the millions of unsigned bands, their fans, and the independent labels that made MySpace a force in the music business. Now the corporate giants are moving in, and some indies fear they may be pushed aside.

On the other hand, MySpace probably feels the need to play to its strengths. It is one of the web's most popular destinations, along with sites such as Wikipedia and YouTube. It has more than 100 million users, but it is under increasing pressure from Facebook, a rival social networking site.

MySpace and Facebook are, of course, dramatically different. MySpace home pages tend to be big, brightly coloured and jam packed with digital bling. They often include music and video streams.

Facebook pages are more formal, far more sober, and most of them look much the same. MySpace tends to be hedonistic and leisure-oriented, while Facebook is more university and career oriented. Many users have, of course, signed up for both.

But thanks to MySpace Music, users could spend more time at MySpace, and add shopping to their socialising. That's the plan.

The Labour party conference saw announcements from the home secretary, Jacqui Smith, and the minister for women and equality, Harriet Harman, revealing that local authorities are to be given greater powers to regulate lap-dancing clubs. This followed news that, in contrast, delegates at the Conservative party conference in Birmingham received discount vouchers for a local lap-dancing club.

The government's announcement is to be welcomed. For four years the lap-dancing industry has enjoyed being subject to no more scrutiny than that given to cafes or karaoke bars. This has been the case since a loophole in the Licensing Act 2003 boxed lap-dancing clubs into a "one size fits all" licensing category primarily designed for the leisure industry. Yet, as Object's campaign Stripping the Illusion highlights, lap-dancing clubs clearly have more in common with peep shows or sex cinemas – licensed as sex establishments – than with Starbucks.

Wholly inadequate licensing has acted as a green light to the industry – which unsurprisingly has doubled in size since 2004. The ensuing mainstreaming of lap-dancing clubs, increasingly popular venues for corporate entertainment, lads' nights out, and stag dos, has alarmed both organisations campaigning towards gender equality and those working on the frontline of violence against women. It has also led to wider debate: tonight's episode of Dispatches on Channel 4, for example, is investigating the increase in the number of lap-dancing clubs in Britain.

In a society crawling to women's equality at a snail's pace, where rape convictions are the lowest for any crime, and where many women continue to be blamed for sexual assault committed against them, something is clearly still wrong with our attitudes towards sex and relations between women and men. The spread in recent years of "sex object culture" – the sexualisation of women's and girl's bodies in the media and popular culture – in a way that has little parallel for boys or men, therefore needs urgent addressing. The dehumanisation of women into sex objects, not people, is a key attitude underpinning inequality and violence. The normalising of lap-dancing clubs fits squarely into this culture.

So it is that an issue such as licensing can directly contribute to sexist attitudes running right through the centre of our society. Yet due to the Licensing Act 2003 loophole, the current licensing system views the social impact of lap-dancing clubs to be no greater than that of cafe bars. This has also led to a loss of democracy in licensing processes. Local communities wishing to have a say in licensing of lap-dancing clubs are confronted with processes that tie the hands of local authorities (pdf) from acting on their concerns.

The key question therefore is whether the government's promise to take action will see legislation introduced sooner rather than later. Object, lobbying alongside the Fawcett Society, is calling for lap-dancing clubs to be licensed as Sex Encounter Establishments (SEEs) – venues that offer visual entertainment for sexual stimulation. This will untie the hands of local authorities by recognising, regulating and licencing lap-dancing clubs for what they are – part of the commercial sex industry. The measure is supported by a broad range of organisations, from Rape Crisis England and Wales and the White Ribbon Campaign to the Local Government Association.

Object and the Fawcett Society are organising a public event to spell out the need to translate these promising announcements into action. The time to act is now: closing the loophole will send out a powerful message that buying a lap dance has a far greater social impact than buying a cappuccino.

As this blog reported in mid-August, at least one shrewd and well-connected political figure in Scotland had his doubts that McConnell would ever take up his post as high commissioner to Lilongwe.

It didn't seem a widely accepted view; McConnell and Scottish Labour officials insisted his move to Malawi was never in doubt. But on Saturday, the former Scottish Labour leader and defeated first minister emerged as Gordon Brown's part-time plenipotentiary of peace while staying on as MSP for Motherwell.

He will now become a special Foreign Office envoy on capacity-building in conflict-torn countries such as Kosovo and Rwanda – a "serious job to deal with serious issues" says McConnell.

Until the 2011 Holyrood elections, that is. McConnell has carefully left this option open. Can we expect him to resign his seat then? I think we probably can.

So Labour's defeat in the Glasgow East byelection in July has had several significant, even bloody, effects, all of which suggest that Gordon Brown's apparent disinterest in and complacency about his party's fortunes in Scotland is over.

Alex Salmond described McConnell's new role it as "blatant political manipulation in order to avoid defeat in a by-election".

The two men charged with holding Glasgow East – David Cairns and Frank Roy – have been knifed, one way or another. Their boss, Des Browne, was dumped as defence secretary on Friday, so then jumped altogether.

Cairns resigned as Browne's deputy – his dignity intact and perhaps enhanced – after Downing Street insiders pushed him into it.

Roy, a canny Labour whip and fixer, was originally touted as the coordinator for the Glenrothes byelection (expected on November 6), repeating his role in Glasgow East. No longer. That proposal has been comprehensively killed off and he went for a three-week break in the US instead.

Roy's tactic of focusing heavily on mobilising the Labour vote in Glasgow is now disparaged.

The Glenrothes campaign is now firmly in the hands of a close-knit team of Fifers, including rising stars such as John Park, a newly elected MSP and former trade unionist at one of the local Labour movement's power bases, Rosyth dockyard.

The SNP spent the last year softening up the seat, knowing that John MacDougall was terminally ill. Labour has tried to counter that by stringing out the byelection date. In the seven weeks since MacDougall's funeral, Labour's machine has run an intense local campaign, with carefully placed anti-SNP stories in Fife's clutch of local papers, and exclusive interviews with the PM for local papers and radio stations.

The resignation of Brownite special adviser Paul Sinclair as Downing Street's Scottish media spinner last month may not be as calamitous to Brown as it appears: Sinclair had fallen out with key people in Holyrood's press corps, so his effectiveness was in question.

If this was not political enough, there is even a cabinet level post now dedicated to saving Brown's legacy, Scottish Labour and the union. Jim Murphy was made a full time secretary of state for Scotland last Friday.

Murphy now has a £7.8m budget and 55 staff at his disposal at the Scotland Office, and not much legislation to worry about. He was very keen on getting the post, and lobbied Brown for the role: he badly wants to be nat-basher-in-chief.

No wonder the SNP are crying foul. Angus Robertson's, the SNP's leader in Westminster, remarked: "The game is up for the Scotland Office – which is clearly just a publicly-funded campaigning vehicle for the Labour party."

But these manoeuvres are probably the best compliment of all to the SNP; as we reported last week, Alex Salmond bemoaned Labour's ineptitude and the lack of a Mandelson figure to put up some decent opposition. It seems he got his wish. Big time.

Not much chance of any bright spots amongst the gloom at the moment. Overnight Libor - the rate at which banks lend to each other - has jumped for the dollar, pound and euro, more evidence if it were needed of the continuing strains in the financial system.

Investors are hoping that the government will come good with its weekend hints that it will do something dramatic to ease the funding crisis in the banking system.

If a week is a long time in politics, 12 months is surely an eternity. A year ago Brown still bounced. Cameron was having to make the speech of his life to save his skin, facing what looked like an imminent general election likely to conclude in the Tories' fourth successive defeat. Today consistent Conservative poll leads have led many to write off Labour's chances for 2010 and view Cameron as a prime minister in waiting. And Comment is free is collecting blogs that address the question "Is the Future Conservative"?
If we're looking at one-word answers surely the reply must be a resounding "no". Admittedly now that it looks like they have a prospect of power, there seems to be more interest in Tory ideas than at any time since their long spell in opposition began. Labour thinktanks such as the IPPR have been selling their wares to the other side and veteran radical-left publishers Lawrence and Wishart, whose biggest grossing titles are Marx in the original, have just published a zeitgeisty e-book on new Conservative thinking (pdf). Yet if you put aside the admiration expressed for Thatcher to the Tory faithful by Cameron at their conference and consider what those ideas actually are emerging from his green papers, the answer is that there's nothing much that'd be out of place in the New Labour bible. For the time being the future consists of the Conservative party aping of New Labour. The postwar Butskellite consensus has been replaced by a post cold war/Berlin Wall/Thatcher consensus that Cameron and Brown both labour under.

The few policies that have been unveiled in the past week are a confused ragbag. Wanting more regulation in the financial sector and rushing to Gordon Brown's side to fight the fires of global capitalism in crisis contradicts earlier positions the Conservatives have taken. Populism must inform Tory support for have-a-go-heroes (homeowners who kill burglars) and freezing council tax. But announcing an expansion of academy schools is surely an attempt to out-New Labour New Labour, in the same way that the "tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime" soundbite once whipped the law and order rug from under the Tories feet. The Conservatives' ostentatious halting of plans for a third runway at Heathrow last week is ostensibly a radical green solution but its chief inspiration was the arc of marginal commuterbelt seats in the shadow of the flightpath.

Elsewhere a rightwing moralism dictates the tax breaks for married couples that JK Rowling tore into when dispatching her million quid to Labour. Step back, though, and in terms of broader rhetoric there is bigger picture talk of "corporate social responsibility" and sticking to Labour's spending pledges. Substitute in the name of economist Richard Thayler (pioneer of the theory of "nudge theory") for Anthony Giddens or Will Hutton (Remember the "third way" and the "state we're in"?) and it all could all bring on an odd sense of déjà vu for anyone old enough to remember or care.

For the moment the Tories are too timid to upset New Labour's thrice election-winning formula of public service investment with an acceptance of the framework of market economics. Hence we are solemnly warned there will be no Tory tax cuts. Indeed he 10p debacle shows how passé slashing taxes is. Even while the majority were 2p in the pound better off, widespread outrage caused a government climbdown that couldn't save the Crewe and Nantwich seat. Amid Cameron's Thatcher namedropping the BBC counted the use of the word "society" 23 times in his main conference speech – something Lady T famously thought there was no such thing as.

David Cameron's self-portrayal as blokey Smiths fan who suns it on the beach in Cornwall with his young family while preferring exclusive foreign hols on the sly is living proof of the success of New Labour: a plastic Blair. Ditto Nick Clegg. When I interviewed amiable Dagenham backbencher Jon Cruddas he called all this "cross-dressing" and commented: "It's almost physiologically they're all merging into one." All around us the evidence is there: it is New Labour who has won the battle of ideas and the Conservatives who have surrendered to the dictum that "if you can't beat 'em join 'em" or rather, ape them. In the 18 months that remain until the next election the Labour party must convince the British public of the hollowness of Cameron's con trick.

The shooting of Jean Charles de Menezes was down to "terrible and extraordinary circumstances" and was not a result of wrongdoing by officers, the senior policewoman in charge of the operation told an inquest today.

Deputy Assistant Commissioner Cressida Dick was in the Scotland Yard control room during the pursuit of the innocent Brazilian electrician.

De Menezes, 27, was shot seven times in the head at Stockwell tube station in south London on July 22 2005 by police marksmen after being mistaken for the terrorist Hussain Osman, who was on the run.

Jean Charles's mother, Maria Otone de Menezes, attended the inquest at the Oval cricket ground for the first time today to hear Dick's evidence.

Asked what went wrong, Dick said: "One thing that clearly went wrong was that we as a nation did not manage to prevent those attacks on July 7 or indeed Hussain Osman and others' attacks on the 21st.

"Mr De Menezes was the victim of some terrible and extraordinary circumstances the day afterwards."

She said the electrician had been "unfortunate" to live in the same block as the terrorist, to look "very like Hussain Osman" and to have entered the same tube station that three of the bombers had entered the day before.

Other factors she said contributed to the "awful tragedy" were the fact that the first surveillance officer had been "indisposed" and that the Brazilian only waited at the bus stop for a short time, leaving little time "to look at him properly".

Dick said that De Menezes "in all innocence - the way he behaved, the way he came off the bus and on the bus - contributed to my assessment of him as a bomber from the day before, and someone who might be intent on causing an explosion today".

The inquest heard that on the morning of the shooting Dick went to the wrong room and missed the start of an important meeting of senior officers to discuss strategy.

She said that when she arrived at the 7am meeting 15 minutes late she did not recall everyone being present. "I had the feeling that it might have been going on for some time before I was there."

Dick told the inquest she was Scotland Yard's most experienced commander of high-risk firearms operations in the years before De Menezes's shooting and was called into action "literally on a daily basis".

A senior brigadier's candour about the prospects of beating the Taliban in Afghanistan must have given the new defence secretary John Hutton a bit of jolt just days into his new job. But he should welcome the remarks of Brigadier Mark Carleton-Smith about British strategy as a cue for a reality check.

It isn't the only urgent problem in the new minister's in-tray. In fact, it is one of several that will need addressing sooner rather than later – and by that I mean in the next few weeks. It isn't that his predecessor, Des Browne, didn't care. He is said to have been privately anguished by the level of deaths and injuries of British servicemen and women in a conflict in which they have been involved over a longer period than the second world war.

The problem is that both Browne and his prime minister avoided public pronouncements about the aim of British strategy in Iraq and Afghanistan, what it might realistically achieve and when the troops could come home.

The problems now facing Hutton are that British forces and their equipment are facing exhaustion after five-and-a-half years in Iraq and seven in Afghanistan. Though most of the troops will come out of Iraq next summer, they will do so with little sense of success and with the opprobrium of the Americans, the ally whose cause took them there in the first place.

The British division will pull out of Basra by midsummer, to be replaced by a US divisional command. In theory this should save between £500m and £750m from the UK budget. But it probably won't. Replacing their kit, training and redeployment – most likely to Afghanistan – will eat up a large slice of that saving.

In Afghanistan the dilemma is different, more dangerous and complex. There are now signs of a serious difference in approach between Britain and America. Increasingly the international effort in Afghanistan is becoming an all-American run show. The American commander General David McKiernan commands the international support and assistance force to the Karzai government (Isaf) as well as commanding the US operation enduring freedom against al-Qaida and its allies in George W Bush's global "war on terror" (GWOT). He is running a split command, and different missions.

"Increasingly the allies, even the ones doing the fighting like the Canadians, Dutch, Danes and Brits are becoming bit players – a sideshow," a British commander told me recently. "This is now an American mission."

The new American commander for US forces across the region, General David Petraeus, believes he can use the same tactics he has just employed in Iraq. He wants there now to be a surge of allied forces into Afghanistan in the way he believes that the surge of 35,000 extra American forces into Iraq have turned round security there – though some say the picture isn't as simple as that. He is preparing to dispatch a further 15,000 US forces to Kabul by the spring. On his visit to London last week he was evidently seeking the UK government to match this by sending the bulk of the forces being pulled out of Iraq next year of around 3,500 to Afghanistan.

The most Britain can send now is a few hundred extra specialists, engineers, signalers, logisticians and the like. There is an unspoken reluctance to commit further because of misgivings about the American approach to spreading the war into Pakistan and because the British defence budget is bust – or even worse than bust. In July, Bush signed an unpublished operational order authorising American ground forces as well as drones and aircraft to raid into Taliban and al-Qaida sanctuary zones inside Pakistan.

Now there is full-scale war across the North-West Frontier Province, the Federally Administered Tribal Area (Fata) and hitherto peaceful districts like Swat. According to New York Times reports this weekend, hundreds of thousands of refugees are fleeing – some so desperate that they are seeking safety inside Afghanistan – as the Pakistan army takes on Taliban affiliates. The Americans believe that the al-Qaida command of Osama bin Laden is hiding in the remoter parts of Fata.

However, al-Qaida seems to be resurgent and particularly active with a new offensive by its allies in Kashmir. Critics say that the American raids in Afghanistan and in the border areas are rapidly alienating the uncommitted in the population. The international command in Kabul has estimated that international forces may have killed up to 4,500 non-combatant civilians this year already. "This means they may occasionally be able to win over the minds of the tribal communities temporarily, with schemes and subsidies," a former SAS commander told me this summer. "But I think we've lost their hearts."

The signs are, too, that despite American and Pakistani efforts, the terrorist campaigns of Taliban and al-Qaida are spreading deep into Pakistan – witness the bombing of the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad and bombings in India. There is also rising tension between India and Pakistan – and some fear another Indian-Pakistan standoff, or even conflict, is on the horizon. This time both parties have nuclear weapons.

The spread of conflict is becoming so complex that it is unlikely the present American strategy and concept of operations can stop things getting much worse, and soon. This is the real fear of commanders like Carleton-Smith and the British ambassador to Kabul, Sir Sherard Cowper-Coles, in his private warning to his French colleague that present strategies are "doomed to failure".

For British ministers like Hutton, the picture is made darker still by the disastrous state of defence finances. Equipment programmes that should run at an average of £16bn over the next 10 years are now expected to soar to more than double that at £35bn. There are problems with big-ticket items such as the new Nimrod surveillance plane and the recently installed Bowman communications system (at £2.2bn) that cannot meet today's requirements for battlefield and strategic communications. The extra £3bn for the Astute submarine programme for this year and the next has already been blown, according to defence industry sources and more funds will be required to get the programme up and running fully. Some in-house MoD analysts and critics are warning that Britain cannot afford to run all three armed services at their present premier division level – some even say that the navy may have to choose between running aircraft carriers and submarines.

"Things are really about to implode," a senior MoD advisers said privately this last week. Gordon Brown had hoped that he could put off a proper defence and security review until after the next election. Now he and his new defence secretary may find they are forced to carry one out very soon. It cannot be the usual "carry on chaps" approach of so many recent policy utterances from MoD in recent years.

This time it will have to assess what Britain really needs and can really do for its own security – and that doesn't necessarily mean treating America as the senior partner at all turns.

This time the review will have to be properly costed – which the last one, in 1998, was not. For it to have any realistic and lasting value it will also have to examine what we have learned from our mistakes and shortcomings since we went piling into Afghanistan and then Iraq since 2001. It is too late for protecting tender egos: a grown-up inquest into the Afghan and Iraq campaigns may avert even worse disasters ahead.

You could imagine Mick McCarthy's team-talk on Saturday: with key players out and the team coming off a heavy midweek loss he'd have wanted his players to make sure they didn't concede an early goal. They were 1-0 down within 26 seconds and went on to lose to Swansea 3-1. McCarthy – correctly given Swansea's home form and the absence of Sylvan Ebanks-Blake, Michael Kightly and Chris Iwelumo – refuses to panic.

"I'd rather be top than second but we can't complain. We have 22 points from 10 games," said McCarthy. "If that's a crisis, then roll on the next crisis."

Besides, too much criticism of Wolves takes away from what was a good performance by Swansea, who have been by far the best of the promoted sides and are still undefeated at the Liberty Stadium.

• Wolves were replaced at the top of the table by Birmingham City, who ground out the dullest of 1-0 victories over QPR. Despite the club's lofty position there's still a fair amount of discontent at St Andrew's, with attendances low and David Sullivan complaining about the lack of atmosphere at home games. Depressingly for Blues fans, it's almost exactly the same situation as last time Blues were in the Championship, with good league form countered by small crowds and Sullivan threatening to sell (although some fans wouldn't see that as a negative).

Despite his adult-orientated background, Sullivan has done much to modernise a traditionally unstable club. However, some – OK, most - of the football Blues have played this season has been ultra-cautious, which has been particularly disappointing given the way they went down with a bit of verve at the end of last season.

• Reading, on the other hand, continue to take on opponents with a ferocity bordering on the psychotic. They'd scored 17 goals in their five previous games at the Madejski and continued that form as they beat Burnley 3-1, a result that raised them to third in the table. There seems to be a determination to prove that last season was an aberration. Stephen Hunt, who has been relentless, embodies that appetite, something that Steve Coppell noted on Saturday: "He plays flat out in an old-fashioned way, and the fans love that."

• At the other end of table, Barnsley have been suffering from the season after the FA Cup semi-final before. After 49 minutes they were 1-0 down to fellow strugglers Doncaster, Darren Moore had been sent off and cries of "Davey out" had begun to float around Oakwell. Amazingly they came back to win 4-1 (thanks in no small part to one of the goals of the season from Jamal Campbell-Ryce). If only Juande Ramos could get his players to fight like that.

• Southampton had put together a few decent results recently, and Jan Poortvliet's side must have been fairly confident ahead of their trip to Coventry. They started well and continue to play some pretty football, but their defending was conspicuous in its absence as Coventry won 4-1. Saints, by the way, were on the end of one of the worst penalty decisions of all time, which was followed up by one of the worst penalties of all time as Elliot Ward passed the ball into the grateful arms of Kelvin Davis.

• While Leicester fans can hardly be enjoying life residing in the lower divisions, they're now three points clear at the top of League One. More importantly the next five sides in the division all failed to win at the weekend.

• In the performance of the week, MK Dons thrashed one of those sides, Millwall, 4-0. It was a particularly impressive result considering Millwall's recent record had read P5 W5. Roberto Di Matteo's side now sit just two points off the play-offs.

• There were three 3-3 draws in the Football League this weekend. On Friday night Swindon found themselves 3-0 up at Hartlepool thanks to a Simon Cox hat-trick, before Joel Porter scored a hat-trick of his own, the final goal coming in injury time. Bury's capitulation/Aldershot's comeback was even more impressive. Bury were 3-0 up with less than half-an-hour to go before a 10-minute blitz from Aldershot levelled the game. Cheltenham, meanwhile, came back three times against Brighton.

• Congratulations to Rotherham, who now have the grand total of one point after their victory at the weekend: pretty impressive given that they started the season on –17 after entering administration. By my (very rough) calculations they'd be fourth in the table without the points penalty. The Millers' victims on Saturday were Grimsby, the only team in the Football League without a win. These are extremely worrying times for Mariners fans: their team would be bottom of League Two if it wasn't for the penalties imposed on Luton, Rotherham and Bournemouth and you wouldn't bet against the latter two catching them before the year is out.

• For quote of the week, we return to Reading. The pastry lover's fantasy of choice, Nigella Lawson, revealed her husband had dreamed she was having an affair with Coppell. "The sad thing was that she never actually thought it, it was him," sighed Coppell on Saturday. "He wished it on her - I think she must have pissed him off big time." Lawson was equally damning: "I said to my husband, 'Thanks a lot. You might have made it Mourinho."'
