"As a nation we have no literature," the literary critic Belinsky cries in despair in part one of Tom Stoppard's play The Coast of Utopia, lamenting the influence of European on Russian writers, and stressing the importance of creating a national story of their own.

With storytelling comes a sense of identity. But national literatures evolve in stages, and the need for a literature of one's own changes according to the political situation of the nation in question. A new nation, or a nation struggling to declare its independence, will be driven to create something that is theirs, a literature that tells their national story. But the flux of modern history makes this a more or less impossible task.

"The universal idea speaks through humanity itself, and differently through each nation in each stage of its history," Belinsky says, later in the same speech. The need for a national literature changes according to the moment the nation is experiencing, and Stoppard catches this exactly - on one hand the ardent yearning for one, and on the other, the contingency of the literature on the historical moment.

At Festival America in Paris last weekend, the question of a writer's nationality and ethnic identity preoccupied most of the discussions. Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, the Nigerian-born author of Half of a Yellow Sun, argued for the Nigerian literature to be taught in Nigerian schools. "It's a paradox," she said. "People can be considered educated while knowing nothing about our history. [They] read English books, not Nigerian books! What this means is we really don't have a sense of our own history." Such history, she said, could not be written by outsiders. "The stories of Africa should be written by Africans," she declared.

But not all ethnic groups feel the need to speak of their immediate experiences. Some experiences need telling, while others are too embarrassing or shameful to recount. In a panel on writers and European heritage, Peter Behrens, whose novel The Law of Dreams is about Irish immigrants to Montreal during the Famine, spoke of families so shamed by their poverty and their foreignness that they could not write their stories for several generations. He compared this to the experience of Central American immigrants to Los Angeles, mentioning a Guatemalan woman he saw selling oranges by the roadside. "Her kids aren't going to be interested in writing about that," he said. "It's going to take a few generations before that will become worthy of storytelling. We want to let things sink into a kind of myth, before we confront them."

Nam Le's debut collection of stories The Boat, meanwhile, probes the place of ethnicity in a writer's work once nationality has become an unstable concept. The opening story in the collection, Love and Honor and Pity and Pride and Compassion and Sacrifice, captures a young writer's ambivalence about writing the "ethnic stories" his creative writing tutor in America tells him are "hot" and "relevant". The final story, The Boat, is by contrast a heart-seizing narrative of Vietnamese refugees on a perilous journey to Malaysia.

Le, who was born in Vietnam and raised in Australia, eventually elected simply to write about what he thought was important. "Today, no matter what or where I write about, I feel a responsibility to the subject matter," he said in an interview with his US publisher. "Not so much to get it right as to do it justice." The places Le evokes in his stories - all over the globe, from New York to Tehran to Medellín to Hiroshima - are vividly realised, attesting less to the importance of a writer's ethnic identity than to the power of imagination.

In many cases, it is no longer a question of discussing "pure" national literatures. France and England, notably, have had to come to terms with their colonial past on a literary level as well as a political one. However, each country's response to these new influences can, perhaps, be taken as an indication of the health of that nation. English literature, which stretched through from Chaucer, Shakespeare, Milton, Sterne, Eliot, and Woolf, now extends to Naipaul, Rushdie, and Smith. In France, on the other hand, there is a real resistance to absorb the influences of Francophone writers, in order to "preserve" the French literary tradition. France was glad to accept the Nobel prize for Gao Xingjian, but a writer like Faïza Guène still struggles for recognition by the St-Germain-centric literary scene.

Finally, the greater movement between countries facilitated by the EU, as well as the effects of globalisation, further complicates the concept of a national literature. Behrens mentioned, for example, the recent influx of Polish immigrants to Ireland. "Maybe soon someone will write the Great Novel of Irish-Polish Experience," he said, wryly.

Effective communication and a credible regulator are needed if Uganda's Prosperity for All scheme to improve the financial muscle of rural areas is to be successful, the Daily Monitor reported last week.

Commenting on the Bonna Bagaggawale scheme, Dr Pascal Odoch, one of the Monitor's "panel of experts", said one of its weaknesses was the fact that it was "anchored on a weak financial pivot" – the Savings and Credit Cooperative Organisations (SACCOs), which are not ready to take on the challenge of managing the scheme.

"The numerous SACCOs that have mushroomed all over the country and keep shouting that "they are ready" for general Salim Saleh's [microfinance minister] micro-finance interventions, are themselves plagued with institutional challenges," Odoch wrote.

He added that these organisations needed a regulator, as many of their managers are not qualified for the job. The regulator would ensure SACCOs employed experienced managers.

Information about the scheme also needs to be effectively communicated to the six homesteads per parish that are involved.

The Prosperity for All scheme, launched in October last year, aims to give people living in rural areas a place to save and borrow money to encourage enterprise.

Last month, Barclays announced it was to invest £10m over three years in community finance schemes in developing countries, including Uganda.

President makes HIV/Aids promise

The Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni, this week made a recommitment to fight HIV and Aids, as the country's infection rates begin to rise.

The Daily Monitor reported this week that Museveni wanted to focus on tackling mother to child transmissions.

Speaking at the opening of the 1m Ugandan shillings Baylor College of Medicine-Children's Clinical Centre of Excellence at Mulago Hospital, the president said: "It is important that all pregnant women test and if found with HIV they are given treatment to prevent mother to child transmission."

According to the Monitor, 25,000 children are born with HIV each year.

Uganda has been hailed as a success story for cutting HIV and Aids rates. Between 1990 and 2000, the number of infections fell from around 18% among the general population and 30% among pregnant women to around 5%, but rates are starting to edge up. Museveni blamed this on the Uganda Aids Commission, which he said had become lax in its duties.

Free antiretroviral drugs have been available in Uganda since 2004 and some believe this has led to complacency.

Others believe the president's move away from an ABC (abstinence, be faithful, use a condom) approach to sex education to a pro-abstinence campaign championed by the US has diluted the safe sex message.

Government curbs aid to LRA

The Lord's Resistance Army last week criticised the Ugandan government for encouraging aid agencies to stop providing rebels with food in a bid to force them to sign a peace deal.

The minister for disaster preparedness, Prof Tarsis Kabwegyere, told a conference on cluster bombs in Kampala that denying the rebels food could pressurise them to sign the long awaited deal that would end more than 20 years of fighting in the north of the country.

The LRA is refusing to sign a deal until arrest warrants issued for some of its leaders, including Joseph Kony, by the International Criminal Court, are withdrawn.

The LRA peace delegation chairman, David Nyekorach Matsanga, said Kabwegyere's remarks did not help the peace process and added that the group was capable of feeding itself.

US ban on contraception

Family planning programmes in at least six African countries, including Uganda, face "serious" disruption following a decision by theUnited States Agency for International Development (USAID) to ban Marie Stopes International (MSI) from receiving US-funded contraception.

USAID has instructed staff to force African governments to discontinue the provision of contraception to Marie Stopes, one of the world's leading family planning organisations, because it works with the Chinese government, which the US accuses of "coercive abortion and involuntary sterilisations".
Marie Stopes chief executive Dana Hovig said the organisation did not support coercive abortion or involuntary sterilisation in China or elsewhere. "To the contrary, MSI is one of the few organisations that has worked over the past decade to increase the availability of voluntary, client-centred family planning services in China," said Hovig, who called the USAID decision as "purely political and dangerous to the lives of women". Hovig said the USAID instruction will "seriously disrupt" MSI's family planning programmes in at least six African states, including Ghana, Malawi, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, Uganda and Zimbabwe. In one country, the organisation delivers 25% of all family planning services nationally.

Hovig added: "This senseless decision is likely to have only one clear consequence: the death of African women and girls. And the Bush Administration should answer for that."
Under US law, the government is not allowed to give aid to any organisation that, according to the president, "supports or participates in the management of a programme of coercive abortion or involuntary sterilisation".

USAID said it would do all it could to ensure other groups within the affected countries distributed contraceptives.

Programme to empower women

Women in five African countries are expected to benefit from an $8m United Nations programme to empower women.

The three-year Gender Equitable Local Development programme seeks to give women more access to resources and services at local level through gender-responsive planning and budgeting, and to encourage more women and community involvement in decision-making.

The initiative will be rolled out in local governments in Mozambique, Rwanda, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Tanzania.

"This programme aims to achieve concrete improvement in women's local realities," said the executive director of the UN Development Fund for Women, Inés Alberdi.

"It not only seeks to ensure local governments' accountability to secure women's equitable access to public services and productive assets, but also acknowledges women's agency in shaping decision-making around local plans and budgets."

With a month to go before election day, the McCain campaign took a sharp turn towards the negative over the weekend - and Sarah Palin was in the vanguard.

At three different events in California on Saturday, Palin attacked Obama's associations with Bill Ayers, the former Weather Underground member, accusing the Democratic candidate of "palling around with terrorists".

The attacks drew a sharp response from Obama, who made much of a remark by a McCain adviser, published in the Washington Post, that his campaign was "looking forward to turning the page on this financial crisis".

"They plan to - and I quote - 'turn the page' on the discussion about our economy and spend the final weeks of this campaign launching Swift Boat-style attacks on me," Obama told a crowd in North Carolina, in a speech backed up by a new TV ad. "We are facing the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression, and John McCain wants us to 'turn the page' on talking about the economy?"

Democratic surrogates also said the Obama campaign had given them the go-ahead to start mentioning some of McCain's questionable associations, including his involvement in the Keating Five scandal and his connections to the ultraconservative Council for World Freedom.

The new negativity from the McCain campaign is a response to continuing bad news for the Republicans in the opinion polls: a New York Times analysis at the weekend noted that Obama is now seriously competitive in nine states that voted for Bush in 2004, while McCain is competitive in only four that voted for Kerry.

Obama's associations with Ayers hardly justify the phrase "palling around": they served on a charity board together, and Ayers once hosted a political event for Obama early in his career. And Obama has repudiated Ayers's 1960s radicalism. But the question that seems likely to be most pressing in the coming week is not whether the Palin-led attacks are fair: it's whether they will work.

What to watch for

Obama has no public events scheduled for today. Joe Biden has cancelled his appearances for Monday and Tuesday after the death of his mother-in-law on Sunday. McCain is campaigning in New Mexico and Tennessee; Palin is in Florida.

Tomorrow night, Obama and McCain will return to the limelight, nudging Palin aside, as they appear for the second presidential debate in Nashville, Tennessee, in a "town hall meeting", taking questions from the audience. It's McCain's favourite format.

Latest polls

Gallup's latest daily tracking poll, released yesterday, gave Obama a seven-point lead, at 50%, over McCain's 43%. It was the ninth straight day that the Democrat had had a statistically significant lead. An amusing Rasmussen poll, meanwhile, exposes the depth of the country's annoyance with its Congressmen and women in the wake of the bail-out law passed on Friday: fully 59% of voters, the poll found, would eject the entire Congress if they could.

Quote of the day

"Our opponent ... is someone who sees America, it seems, as being so imperfect, imperfect enough, that he is palling around with terrorists who would target their own country ... This is not a man who sees America as you see America and as I see America": Sarah Palin all but calls Obama a foreigner and a traitor - and not, one suspects, for the last time.

Spoof of the day

Tina Fey excels again on Saturday Night Live, in a spoof of last Thursday's debate. On gay marriage: "I believe marriage is meant to be a sacred institution between two unwilling teenagers."

ITV1's The X Factor pulled in 9.8 million viewers and a 41% share between 7.45pm and 9.15pm compared with 9.2 million and 40% for BBC1's Strictly Come Dancing between 6.45pm and 8pm, according to unofficial overnight figures.

Today's Independent launched a 24-page sports section but ditched its stand-alone media supplement. Some people are bound to see this as confirmation that the editor, Roger Alton, is a great sports fan. But it's obvious that sport is a bigger draw for readers than media pages.

Advertisers for sports sections, however, are almost impossible to attract. Media buyers refuse to see the value in placing ads on some of the best-read pages of newspapers. The belief is that men who consume sport do not to consume much else. So there is just one paid-for advert in the new Indy section.

It's a pacey, colourful section with a terrific poster picture on its spread, but devoid of lengthy analytical reads. I liked the Brian Viner interview with Aston Villa's Ashley Young, especially the anecdote about receiving a call from the former England manager, Steve McLaren. Overall, a good opening goal or Alton.

The movement of the media section into the main paper has not noticeably diminished its coverage of the topic despite it getting less space. There are seven busy pages at the back of the book, following business. Matthew Norman's diary remains, as do the columns, on the press by Stephen Glover, and on advertising by Claire Beale.

The main feature, by former Press Gazette editor Ian Reeves, looks at the possibility of the internet suffering another economic crash, based in part on last week's speech by Trinity Mirror's ceo, Sly Bailey, about a coming "digital slump". The final two-thirds of his article quotes people who believe it isn't going to happen... maybe.

The Indy's ditching of its media section was prefigured in yesterday's first full-colour issue of the Independent on Sunday, which reduced its media coverage to a single page.

There has been a pronounced retreat from media coverage by the national press in the last couple of years. The Telegraph titles do very little nowadays, if any. The Times carries a regular, and readable, media business column by Dan Sabbagh, but not much else. The days of the Sunday Times's newspaper column, by Brian MacArthur, are long distant.

The Financial Times sticks, as you would expect, to the business end. None of the middle-market daily or Sunday papers bother with coherent media coverage, nor do the red-tops. (For the Daily Mail and The Sun, media coverage means taking lumps out of the BBC at every opportunity).

The Indy clearly has not given up on media, because seven pages out of 48 shows continuing commitment. But it never did manage to lure advertisers away from The Guardian's media section, the first of its kind and still going strong despite the noticeable down-turn in media advertising, so its supplement was an on-cost with, presumably, too little audience appreciation.

Yet "the media" is a part of modern life that deserves to be monitored consistently. Its influence appears to grow rather than diminish. There needs to be public scrutiny of the people who own and control the various media platforms and of those who manage and operate it on behalf of those owners and controllers.

Despite its scant resources, The Independent has played, and is playing, a part in keeping the media honest. Why do so many other serious papers ignore it, I wonder?

The (de)merits of believing what you read about Hollywood in the UK tabloids have been discussed ad nauseam. However, the Sun's report today that Kate Winslet is to play Vivienne Westwood in a new biopic looks bona fide enough: the newspaper's story features confirmation from a spokeswoman for the fashion designer. This rumour was all over the place following whispers at Paris fashion week, but as there are no other details of cast, crew or director we can only assume that the movie is in the very early stages of being put together, although Hadley Freeman already has a few thoughts on what happens when fashion collides with Hollywood.

Much more definite is Steven Spielberg's split with Paramount, which was officially confirmed today. As previously reported, the Oscar-winning film-maker is to form a new Hollywood-based film venture worth $1.5bn with India's Reliance ADA Group. But never fear, Spielberg apparently retains a good working relationship with his long-time partners in DreamWorks and will continue to produce films in the Transformers franchise. Phew.

Elsewhere, Empire reports that the Stoker clan have sold the film rights to the forthcoming officially approved sequel to Dracula (that's the 1897 novel by Bram). The new book has been written by the latter's great-grandnephew Dacre Stoker, apparently in accordance with notes left by his illustrious ancestor for a second book. Dacre has also had help from award-winning Dracula documentarian and historian Ian Holt, and the title, Dracula: the Undead, also originated with Bram. So it's all as official as official can be. Holt has also written a screenplay with Alexander Galant, and the film should start shooting in June 2009. Speed director Jan de Bont is producing.

Finally, Michael Douglas will be presented with the American Film Institute's lifetime achievement award at a tribute event in Los Angeles in June. Fittingly, it's the same award his father took home in 1991. Douglas hasn't been seen much on our screens recently, following 2007's King of California. But he has four films on his slate, including a biopic of Liberace and a film in which he'll play a sex addict, so with a bit of luck the award won't mark the end of an admirably edgy career.

MPs returning to parliament today will find their change includes anti-tuition fee pound coins that campaigners have put into circulation in Westminster.

More than 9,000 coins bearing the motto Free For All are being circulated in the House of Commons to highlight the cost of fees paid by undergraduates for higher education, as students head back to university.

The stunt by the UK Youth Parliament is part of its campaign to abolish tuition fees, which now stand at £3,145 per year at universities in England.

James Greenhalgh, MYP and national campaigns coordinator, said: "There seems to be no end in sight as the cost of university spirals out of control.

"Young people are being asked to play Russian roulette with their financial future as they incur mounting debts.

This week on The X Factor the judges chose the final 12. There were winners and there were losers, but did you agree with the final choices?

By Sunday night, each judge had chosen their final three – and I'm sure a few of you were screaming at the TV: "How could they put that act through?"

It was apparent, more than ever, that in the battle between genuine talent and perceived likeability, talent sometimes lost. And the females had a much tougher ride than the males.

In Dannii's over-25's category, I would argue that background story won over talent. I could see why Dannii made her tactical choices as I imagine she didn't want to put through three women – even though Suzie Furlong, Rachel Hylton and Ruth Lorenzo were the strongest singers. Choosing between Daniel Evans and James Williams, she chose the weaker singer who had the bigger sympathy factor. I feel terrible saying it, but I think having lost his wife was what put Daniel through.

Rachel Hylton has a great voice, with a unique sound and character – which is rare in these competitions. She did a heartfelt version of Christina Aguilera's Beautiful, but forgot the words. It almost seems like she subconsciously finds ways to sabotage her chances. Dannii saw a diamond in the rough and decided to take the risk.

Ruth Lorenzo was not a bad singer, as she continued to charm us with Spanish/English versions of pop songs (in this case, True Colors), but she should not have been picked over Suzie Furlong, who dazzled with One Day I'll Fly Away. Was it Ruth's tears that did it?

Simon Cowell's 14- to 24-year-old boys were not as strong as the girls. Austin Drage is the best of them. After he sang Michael Jackson's She's Out of My Life, Simon Cowell said: "That performance will change that boy's life forever" and, rightly, chose him for his final three.

Scott Bruton sang one of my favourite songs: Bonnie Raitt's I Can't Make You Love Me. I thought it was a lukewarm rendition but, fortunately for Scott, Simon disagreed and put him through.

Eoghan Quinn has a decent voice, but so far I think it lacks character, so singing a Boyzone song was the perfect choice. It certainly won Simon over. Mali, who in the initial auditions had loads of character, must have left it all back in Blighty, and lost out.

Louis Walsh was spot on in his selection in the group category. JLS's version of Jordin Sparks' No Air was shaky at first, but they were blending beautifully by the end. Louis worried that the general public may not get them. Was that because they're all black? Surely not. He chose them.

Bad Lashes made an interesting and brave song choice in Oasis' Wonderwall, and were definitely the best girl group. They also have a great singer in the soloist. This is the group that Louis called "a bunch of hairdressers" in the initial auditions.

Girlband, the third group to get through, didn't really make an impression but, unlike Priority – the boy band put together by the judges – they had actually rehearsed more, and that was enough to give them the edge.

Unlike the other judges, Cheryl picked the songs for her 14- to 24-year-old girls - which was undoubtedly the toughest category. The biggest upset, to me, was that Hannah Bradbeer didn't get through. Her rendition of Piece of My Heart gave me (and the judges) goosebumps. In any other category she would have sailed through. Maybe she can come back in three years, when she's 25.

Diana Vickers sounded hoarse as she struggled through Nothing Compares to You with her eyes closed (and I mean that literally). Still, she's got that indie-girl angle that makes her stand out, so she made it.

Laura White was given a tough tune – Justin Timberlake's Cry Me A River. She was up to the challenge. I have a feeling that it was a choice between her and Hannah, and I'm still not sure if Cheryl made the right decision in going for Laura.

Alexandra Burke may just be another Leona Lewis in the making. Like Cheryl said, she needs to put a bit more of herself in the vocals and show more vulnerability. Everything else seems to already be in place.

From now on, it's up to the viewers. My favourites of the finalists are Alexandra, Austin, Rachel and Bad Lashes. Which ones are yours? Can you already see the winner among the final 12?

Søran Kierkegaard used to tell parables by way of doing philosophy. One went like this. An ancient Greek was asked to define religion. He asked for time to prepare an answer. When the agreed period had elapsed he asked for some more time, and then more, and more, and so on. In short, he refused to answer. "In this way," Kierkegaard concludes, "he wished to express symbolically that he regarded the question as unanswerable".

In the last few days, two pieces of research have hit the headlines purporting to show some aspect of how religion works, and indeed that it does work. One claimed that believers gazing upon images of the Virgin Maryfelt less pain than a control group. Another that religious convictions about the supernatural make us more honest and trusting. Both utilise common assumptions about belief, in the first case that it serves mostly to provide consolation, in the second that it is about avoiding the wrath of moralising gods.

The researchers would do well to ponder Kierkegaard's story, or even better, consult a theologian – that is to say, an expert – before presuming too much about the phenomenon they seek to study.

If they did, they might avoid some of the potty conclusions they reach. For example, the Virgin-eases-pain story included the possibility that Our Lady's analgesic works as well for lapsed Catholics as mass goers. Should this be taken as support for the theological conviction that God is faithful even when we are not?

The serious point is that religions are massively diverse. Many Christians and Muslims may seek salvation from punishment in heaven. Hindus, Buddhists and Sikhs don't. And as for Jews, the third of the Abrahamic religions, "the idea of Hell and eternal damnation is foreign", according to the Chambers Dictionary of Belief and Religions. Even within one religion, ideas will differ enormously.

Another thing that is striking about the researchers' understanding of religion is how belief in God is interpreted as a kind of cost-benefit analysis. This piece of economics is, in turn, justified by a certain kind of evolutionary theory. But you don't need to turn to theologians or philosophers to find unease with such Darwinism.

The primatologist Frans de Waal expressed the concern well in his book Our Inner Ape.

At the same time that Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher preached that greed was good for society, good for the economy, and certainly good for those with anything to be greedy about, biologists published books in support of these views.

He is particularly concerned about the notion that altruism stems from egoistic motives, goodwill that arises from the mutual scratching of backs. "Love is unheard of, sympathy is absent, and goodness a mere illusion," he writes. The critique is all the more powerful since it is not based on philosophical concerns but on empirical evidence. De Waal believes that the chimps and bonobos he has observed understand, demonstrate and even value genuine altruism and empathy.

That there is something distinctly post-Thatcherite about the cost-benefit approach to religion is also suggested by comparing what previous generations of sociologists and economists made of belief. Durkheim is the outstanding example, notably in his seminal study Suicide. It showed that the greater a sense of obligation people have, the less likely they are to want to end it all. And that religion provides the best ties of all.

However, Durkheim was enough of a theologian to realise that it is not beliefs about divinities per se that count. Rather it is the connection with other people that religious practice nurtures which is so valuable. Confessional statements are but a secondary expression of that belonging. Praxis counts, not doxis. In other words, contemporary research that focuses on what people may say about God, puts the cart before the horse. Religion is not the cause, it is the expression of the meaning and significance people find in their lives. It is that meaning and significance which – let us say for the sake of argument – leads them to, say, feel less pain or trust others more.

By interpreting religion from within an essentially economic theory, the researchers exclude what might actually be true about belief. For maybe agnostics, like myself, and atheists should be more open to religion's challenge? Mightn't it be the case that belief is associated with greater degrees of trust because believers have seen that the world can actually be trusted? Or to put it another way, just because we have evolved into meaning-seeking creatures doesn't mean there isn't meaning out there to be found.

Banks and miners are leading the market lower on another Black Monday, as the financial crisis spreads still further.

Suggestions that the UK government might take stakes in troubled banks and guarantee all savers' deposits - following the weekend's volte-face by the Germans - have added to the sense of events spiralling out of control.

The credit crunch contagion has led to hasty weekend meetings to bail out a host of European banks, from Hypo Real Estate to Fortis, but the fear is that more may follow. The idea that the UK would be prepared to part nationalise any struggling bank has set investors worrying about whether there are other UK institutions already in trouble.

"European governments are looking to stabilise the financial sector by attempting to rescue some major institutions," said Chris Hossain of spread betters ODL Securities. "Whilst their actions are understandable, the smell of desperation remains strong. One has to question what the next steps will be if this fails to ensure market stability."

With last week's dominant factor - the $700bn US bank bail-out - seemingly sorted out, attention has also turned to the growing threat of recession in the US and elsewhere. So oil and other commodities have fallen back on fears of slowing demand. Copper is down some 5%, while oil has dropped around 4% to $87 a barrel.

All this has left the FTSE 100 227.6 points lower at 4752.6, with not a single gainer in the leading index.

HBOS is the biggest faller so far, down nearly 16% to 168.9. Lloyds TSB, which is planning to take over the mortgage bank, is 7.5% lower at 268.75p, while Royal Bank of Scotland is off 11.5% at 164.8p.

Credit Suisse believes the problems in the underlying economy mean bank shares will fall further.

"The fundamental issues facing the banks do not justify current share prices in our view (on a 6-12 month investment horizon)," it said. "Trading at around 1.2 times tangible book value, we think the downturn that is coming is absolutely not factored into current share prices."

Among the miners, Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation has fallen 86p to 469p, while Kazakhmys is down 71.5p at 497.5p.

Xstrata fell 146p to £15.34p as Citigroup cut its target price from £50 to £36.80 to reflect the decline in metals prices. It did however keep a buy recommendation on the shares.

Citi said: "We believe that Xstrata's decision to not make an offer for
Lonmin given the current uncertainty in financial and debts markets was the right move for shareholder value. The company's balance sheet is expected to improve dramatically over the next two years and by 2010 we have Xstrata in a cash position.

"Xstrata's purchase of the additional 14.2% of Lonmin's stock at £19.79, (taking its total stake to 24.9%), may provide a blocking position. We believe Xstrata could wait out the required 12 month period to make a lower offer than the £33.00 they paid for the original 10% stake on 6 August 2008. In the meantime the company can focus on its internal growth options and arguably repurchase its own shares."

Iron ore specialist Ferrexpo is 13.75p lower at 103.75p, after its biggest shareholder Fevamotinico, controlled by Ukrainian billionaire Kostyantin Zhevago, sold a 21.8% stake to Czech coal group New World Resources.

A suspected Tamil Tiger suicide bomber killed 27 people in Sri Lanka today, including an opposition leader, the country's military said.

At least 69 more were wounded in the attack on the new office of the opposition United National party in Anuradhapura, 130 miles north-east of the capital, Colombo, according to the military spokesman Brigadier Udaya Nanayakkara.

Retired Major General Janaka Perera, who was killed in the blast along with his wife, was the leader of the party in the north-central provincial assembly.

During his military career he led many successful campaigns against the separatist Tamil guerrillas in the long-running civil war. He was feted for his role in halting a major rebel advance in the Jaffna peninsula, the cultural heartland of the country's minority Tamils, in 2000. He was elected to the assembly in August.

Nanayakkara said the bomber was a Tamil Tiger rebel who apparently targeted Perera because of his successes against the separatists during his years in the military.

The United National party accused the government of ignoring repeated requests for a stronger security detail for Perera, an open critic of the military's strategy in its fight against the rebels.

"The government must take full responsibility. They did not give him adequate security for political reasons," a party official, Tissa Attanayake, said.

Hours before the attack, a roadside bomb killed two civilians and wounded another in a village near Anuradhapura. The ancient city is a popular tourist destination, housing some of the country's holiest Buddhist sites.

Rebel officials could not be reached for comment on either attack because communication lines have been cut to guerrilla-dominated areas in the north.

The Tamil Tigers have been under pressure from Sri Lankan troops who have been advancing on the group's political capital of Kilinochchi. The group has recently lost control of territory in the north of the country to the military.

The Tamil Tigers began fighting in 1983 to create an independent homeland for the country's ethnic minority Tamils who complain of discrimination at the hands of successive governments controlled by majority ethnic Sinhalese. More than 70,000 people have been killed in the violence.

London-based Zoo Qoo launched in August this year as a creative showcase to promote talented game designers, photographers writers, musicians and the rest of the creative community. With a small staff of two full-timers and four part-timers and his own cash, Rich Wilson wants to help promote the creative industries but also spot some stars - and make commission on their work.

Wilson explains how it works.


ZooQoo founder Rich Wilson

• Explain your business to my Mum.
"Zoo Qoo is an online talent showcase and creative publishing network. The site allows users to publish their work through one of twelve creative categories ranging from music to photography, fashion to architecture, art to games. Users can either publish their work for free or sell it through our digital marketplace. They can then link to other artists, rate and review work by others or just look at content on the site. The strong underlying theme is quality over quantity; we ensure this high standard of content by asking the Zoo Qoo Council to vet all work pre-publication."

• How does that work?
"The Zoo Qoo Council, currently made up of over 150 site aficionados all dedicated to the creative cause, must give entries at least five "yes" votes but no more than two "no" votes before publication. Going in front of the council is basically make or break point for the artist's entry and a watertight way of ensuring quality is maintained throughout the site. Anything we genuinely take a shine to will be passed around our growing list of industry insiders and talent scouts. The ultimate aim is to put high quality grassroots talent onto a global platform; we've had some success to date but are still waiting for that first 'golden' signing."

• How do you make money?
"A combination of premium ad inventory, sponsorship deals, account upgrades, commission from the digital marketplace and merchandise."

• Any weird business experiences so far?
"How much time you got?"

• What's your background?
"I studied architectural engineering at Leeds but having worked for Ove Arup for six months, I began to realise that the construction industry in the UK was more about arbitration and mediation than the realisation of people's dreams. I travelled the world working in a rodeo, a circus sideshow, a mayonnaise factory; I worked as a rabbit-hutch maker, a gardener, a painter- and then came home to establish my own jewellery design business and write a book on Zoo Qoo."

• Are we in the middle of a new dot com bubble?
"I'd say we're towards the end of the bubble. All of the big acquisitions made over the past two years have, by now, proved that the investments simply weren't worth the money."

• How many users do you have now, and what's your target within 12 months?
"100,000 per month at present – our target is 1,000,000 per month in 12 months time."

• Which tech businesses or web thinkers are the ones to watch?
"Obviously the big players like Facebook and MySpace. I'm intrigued to see if Google can successfully monetise YouTube too – they still have a large mountain to climb there. I'm looking forward to seeing where Tim Berners-Lee's new semantic web goes and over in Japan they're developing a new "secure" web – I'll be following that one with interest."

• Name your closest competitors.
"LuLu, MySpace, eSnips , Deviant Art, Flickr – they're all linked in some way but maybe not direct competition. The way I see it as a promoter of the arts is that we should all ultimately be trying to help each other achieve success – try telling that to someone like Mr Murdoch though."

• Where do you want the company to be in five years?
"A top 100 global website."

The Film

During the 1960s and 1970s Arthur Penn made a series of films that uncompromisingly engaged with the reality of America's violent past. Penn re-invented the gangster genre with Bonnie and Clyde (1967), a film that re-cast the main protagonists as lovers-on-the-run, in French nouvelle vague style.

Penn's directorial career began with The Left Handed Gun (1958). This was a western story that looked at one of the most compelling stories of the old west – the legend of Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid. The film stars Paul Newman in the role of Billy, with John Dehner as Pat.

The film was an attempt by Penn to unpick the romanticised mythology of the west in Hollywood. The revisionist western of the 1960s and 1970s accepted the arbitrary violence of the wild-west as a product of social, political and economic forces beyond the control or understanding of its cast. Accordingly, the new heroes were presented as composite characters with both good and evil in their natures. Left Handed Gun was originally conceived as a vehicle for James Dean, the poster boy of American teenage anxiety and rebellion during the 1950s.

The revisionist western is, at its most accomplished, a proto-Marxist exposition of the determining forces that shaped the westward American expansion. The genre also includes Once Upon a Time in the West from 1968, and Heaven's Gate (1980). These films refuse the complacent moral judgements used to justify the manifest destiny of western expansion.

Sam Peckinpah's Pat Garrett and Billy the Kidd (1973), with Kris Kristofferson, James Coburn and Bob Dylan was part of a slightly different effort. Peckinpah's project, begun with Ride the High Country (1962) and The Wild Bunch (1969), sought to make a definitive statement about the American west. For Peckinpah, the isolation of the far west removed all but the most basic of determining forces. The result was an unforgiving environment that revealed the moral integrity, or otherwise, of the men and women placed within it. For Peckinpah, failure was always met with a bullet. More recently, Clint Eastwood has explored this version of the west.

The Legend of Pat and Billy

The legend plays itself out against a backdrop of the small, but intensely violent, Lincoln County wars. This conflict pitched the vested interests of ranchers against those of the wider community. The war ranged across New Mexico in America's southwest during 1878.

Billy the Kid was a member of the ranchers' outlaw force, named The Regulators. These enforcers, drawn from criminal elements across the southwest, eventually ran out of control. They were brutally suppressed in a series of bloody shoot-outs. Those that survived were dispersed and forced on the run. The implacable law-man Pat Garrett, eventually tracked, caught and executed Billy in 1881.

The legend of Pat and Billy was mostly created through the sensationalist memoir published by Pat Garrett in 1882. The myth showed Garrett as an enforcer who would follow his prey to the inevitable and bloody conclusion. This myth has been variously recast across American history and in various contexts, so that corruption and lawlessness will never, in the USA, be allowed to go unpunished.

Billy the Kid, like Jesse James, is one of the hero villains of the wild-west. His reputation as a violent killer was tempered by recollections of his friendly and personable character. Surviving photographs of Billy show his appreciation of fine clothes. He was remembered as a neat dresser who favoured an unadorned Mexican sombrero hat. So, Billy survives as both outlaw and folk hero dandy.

The attempt, by revisionist Hollywood, to rehabilitate the western outlaw reached its apotheosis in George Roy Hill's Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969).

The Poster

This week's poster is a piece of ephemera from the Royal College of Art in London. The poster is a simple, rough-and-ready, example of student design and screen-printing.

The design of the poster, narrow portrait, allowed it to be printed two-up on double crown paper measuring 20x30 inches. The poster was printed in a tiny print run for display within the College. The make-ready for screen-printing would have taken a few hours using new photo-mechanical processes.

The poster design is made up of several pictorial elements. These are the map of the USA, the lawman's stripes and the revolver. The map is embellished with a line of letterpress printing, The Western Plains. This second printing, combining two quite separate forms of printmaking would only have been possible within the non-commercial environment of the RCA.

The success, or otherwise, of poster designs at the RCA could always be judged by how many were removed from the walls and how quickly. John Lewis, typographer at the RCA, saved this example.

The RCA

The Royal College of Art played a key role in the transformations of British visual culture during the 1960s. The first generation of post-war designers rejected the sense of established good taste prevailing in Britain at the end of the 1950s. The use of irregular typography, the general references to popular culture, and to American popular culture in particular, were strategies calculated to wind up the old guard.

The conceptualisation of society based around the hedonistic consumerism of experience and lifestyle began in the early 1950s at the ICA in London. The artists and architects associated with the Independent Group rejected established and polite good taste. These artists revelled in the more energetic and visceral possibilities of cultural production.

In this context, it was entirely appropriate that the College Film Society should provide screenings of American, rather than of higher-brow, European art-house films.

The College magazine Ark provides a more permanent legacy of these ideas. The editors recall that their efforts were an attempt to produce a magazine as part of a visual culture whose experience was immediate and exciting. They rejected the usual idea that the work should be about something beyond itself and the immediate here-and-now.

Eventually, these ideas formed the basis of swinging London and its politics of an ephemeral and hedonistic consumption. Later, the same willingness to wind up the establishment formed the basis for the punk counter-culture of the mid 1970s.

The designer of the poster remains unknown. Perhaps it was Brian Haynes who later worked at The Sunday Times Magazine. Maybe it was Brian Tattersfield.

Here in California, supporters of Republican candidate John McCain attending a rally of his running mate Sarah Palin were echoing her attack that Barack Obama enjoys "palling around with terrorists".


Video by Sharona Smith of Voice of Americans2008

Holding up a copy of the New York Times looking into connections between Barack Obama and 1960s radical William Ayers, one supporter shouted:

"Hey Obama! Read this morning's New York Times, Obama! Obama! How about Bill Ayers, Obama!"

There have been several newspaper articles investigating Obama's relationship with Ayers. They have professional connections but aren't close, as the New York Times article finds.

The conservative blogosphere in the US has been much more aggressive than the McCain campaign itself in pushing Obama's connection to 60s radical William Ayers. Just do a search on New York Times Obama whitewash, and you'll see that conservative bloggers don't believe the media's fact checking. But this like other allegations and rumours continue to rumble around the internet. How do these messages spread?

Barack Obama's presidential campaign has faced scrutiny over more than his connection to Bill Ayers. He has also had to rebut online rumours that he secretly is a Muslim, some sort of Islamic Manchurian candidate. Some have even claimed that he is the anti-Christ, although how one would go about proving or disproving that is beyond me. Internet rumour-debunking site Snopes tries.

Of course, Democrats aren't the only ones who face rumours. Sarah Palin herself was forced to reveal that her daughter Bristol Palin was pregnant after rumours circulated online that the vice presidential nominee wasn't the mother of her fifth child.

Usually the source of a rumour is difficult to track down, and it's devilishly difficult to rebut them.

Jon Kleinberg at Cornell University is studying the phenomenon, and he found that instead of spreading virally, like a biological contagion, political rumours often spread quite slowly and take reinforcement. People often wait to hear a message twice before passing it on to a couple of people.

It's not just people forwarding e-mails. Studies have been done looking at the logs of Google searches, and earlier this year, the top two searches for Barack Obama were looking for his biography, but the fifth or sixth most popular search term was "Obama Christian or Muslim".

"People were using the internet to figure this out for once and for all," Kleinberg said.

And these messages are hard to kill off. One of the most popular chain e-mails dates back to a 1995 message saying that the US government was looking to end funding for National Public Radio, the public radio broadcaster in the US. Another perennial favourite is a 1997 e-mail saying that the US government was looking to institute a five cent tax on every e-mail.

More than a decade later, these chain e-mails are still rumbling around the internet. I doubt these political rumours will die in the next 30 days before Americans cast their ballots on 4 November.

The BBC Radio 4 specialist factual commissioning editor, Andrew Caspari, is to leave the station after a decade in the post.

Caspari, who is responsible for around 60 programmes and strands, will be replaced by the Radio 3 editor of arts, Mohit Bakaya, who currently runs topical nightly arts show Night Waves.

The BBC has appointed Caspari as its new head of online speech radio, where he is expected to ensure that sites across the entire network fully integrate relevant radio programmes and content.

He will officially take up his new post on Wednesday.

His Radio 4 job, which accounts for around a quarter of the station's £40m annual programme budget, involves overseeing many of the regular strands which define the network across a range of genres including current affairs, science, law and natural history.

Programmes include Any Questions? and Any Answers?, Yesterday in Parliament, Thought for the Day, File on 4, Front Row, Unreliable Evidence, Ramblings, Feedback, All in the Mind, The Moral Maze, Sunday Worship and, from last week, The Media Show.

Caspari, who joined the Today programme in the 80s after a spell as a presenter on BBC Radio Merseyside, was part of a small team which in 1998 shook up Radio 4 in a controversial overhaul headed by the then controller, James Boyle.

Many of the strands he helped introduce still survive, including Broadcasting House, Front Row, Open Book, The Choice and Material World.

Caspari said of the 1998 revamp: "It became a personal thing, but if we had not taken on sacred cows we would not have got some of the new things on air, which are now so popular.

"I am especially proud of Front Row, which runs every evening at 7.15 pm, and attracts around 2.25 million people a week."

Radio 4 is currently in rude health and is introducing new presenters under controller Mark Damazer. It is generally deemed to have not sacrificed its reputation for quality despite annual cutbacks.

Caspari said he had learned that the Radio 4 audience had "high expectations" of everything.

"While they like the habit and stability of the Radio 4 schedule, they are much more flexible and open-minded and less stuffy about the network than the caricature would have you believe," he added.

"The key for them is a threshold of quality. If what we do is intelligent and original then there is a huge canvas on which to play and vary things."

He said that one of his biggest regrets was not being able to find the right kind of sports talk programme for Radio 4, despite several tries with Late Tackle and Last Man In.

Bakaya stood in last year for Caspari when he took an attachment at the BBC World Service.

So where are we in the Great London Police Drama? Much debate has raged over whether Mayor Johnson's effective ousting of Ian Blair last Thursday was driven by political ideology or a need for more productive policing, or was even an unintended consequence. Friday's Guardian broke the story – repeated everywhere else all weekend – that the outgoing Commissioner was told at the fateful meeting, also attended by Kit Malthouse and MPA chief executive Catherine Crawford, that there would be no rush to replace him because a Tory government was on its way and would deliver a top cop to a Tory mayor's taste.

This suggestion has been sharply denied both on the record and into my right ear as I trudged sleeplessly past Clapton Pond clutching a loaf of bad-for-you bread early on Friday morning. The Guardian, though, sticks by its sources. If only I could tell you everything I've been told about each version of events, well, you still might not know which to believe. I'm trying figure out if there's a way both can be true. It's tough work, I'm telling you.

Attention has since turned to Blair's successor and the manner in which he will be chosen. The formal power to hire and fire remains with the Home Secretary, but Johnson's intervention shows that in the right circumstances his informal power can be decisive. He's now working hard to manage the fallout from this. Strong reactions from West Yorkshire Chief Constable Sir Norman Bettinson, ACPO President Ken Jones (thanks, Troll) and Blair's predecessor Sir John Stevens have demonstrated the resistance among senior policeman to closer control by politicians.

I'm told that Johnson's initial low profile and refusal to answer questions about Blair was motivated by a desire to let him leave with dignity. Whatever, the mayor broke cover on The Politics Show yesterday, dismissing the "political" charge as "poppycock, balderdash and tripe" – wouldn't a simple "bollocks" have sufficed? – and denying that a constitutional precedent had been set. Yet it is difficult to see how Johnson's opinions about candidates for next leader of the Met won't carry more weight now than they would have this time last week.

Who does the mayor have his eye on? Looks like a line can be drawn under speculation that Bill Bratton, the man who implemented Rudi Giuliani's alleged "miracle" in New York – and, inconveniently for "zero tolerance" evangelists, an admirer of Blair - is in the frame. Should we read anything into Kit Malthouse's speaking of the next permanent appointment being a "he or she?"

Search me. But as he prepares to chair the MPA for the first time this morning, Johnson is surely aware that he needs to tread very carefully. Populist button-pushing about removing "political correctness" from policing such as he indulged in (albeit in moderation) during the election campaign will not endear him to ethnic minority officers unappeased by Blair departure and I'm encouraged that, just prior to publishing this post, I read and hear on the Today programme that Johnson is set to launch an inquiry into racism in the Met. He'll need to be very mindful too that stop-and-search a la Blunt 2 remains a potential danger to building the trust with the public that successful policing depends on far more than tech tools like knife arches or crime maps.

For the good of the Met and London as a whole, Johnson needs to still public and police disquiet alike. I'm assured that a return of the damaging, self-defeating, macho "canteen culture" street policing of yore is not considered desirable. The mayor would be wise to spread that message around.
